explanation:
To determine if OS_CondVarLock violates the MISRA rule “a function parameter should not be modified” we must know whether the parameter var_id can be changed in this function or indirectly via any calls or instrumentation. For that we need:

- OS_ObjectIdGetById (prototype/definition): The function is called with var_id. Its prototype shows whether var_id is passed by value or by pointer (e.g., osal_id_t vs osal_id_t *), and whether any macro wrappers convert the argument into an lvalue that could be modified. The implementation will show if it modifies its parameters via side-effects.

- OS_CondVarLock_Impl (prototype/definition): Called with &token; its prototype confirms it does not receive var_id and cannot modify the var_id parameter, but the definition ensures there are no unexpected macros/instrumentation that also touch var_id.

- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr (prototypes/definitions): The static call graph shows these test/stub helpers as callees of OS_CondVarLock (or as instrumentation wrappers). Their prototypes/implementations are required to confirm whether any instrumentation expands into code that modifies the local parameter variable var_id (for example via macros that take &var_id or assign to it).

- osal_id_t (typedef/declaration): Determine whether osal_id_t is an integer (passed by value) or actually a pointer/structure type (in which case passing it could allow indirect modification semantics). Knowing the underlying type is essential to decide if passing var_id could result in modification of the parameter itself.

- OS_object_token_t (typedef/declaration): The local token variable is passed by address; its type lets us verify that &token cannot alias var_id and that no aliasing could cause modification of var_id indirectly.

- int32 (typedef/declaration): Confirms the return type and whether any implicit conversions or macros could alter the parameter as part of return handling (mainly for completeness of prototype analysis).

- OS_SUCCESS, OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR (macro/enum values): These constants are arguments to OS_ObjectIdGetById. Their definitions can reveal whether they are macros that expand to expressions that reference/modify var_id (unlikely but must be checked for macro side-effects).

Collecting the above prototypes/typedefs/definitions allows a precise check that var_id is only used as a value parameter (not passed by address or modified by instrumentation/macros) and that no called function or stub can legally or covertly modify the function parameter itself.
